content: @WG-rustc-dev-guide :wave:
to be honest, I don't have much to share
other than saying that I may start having time to work on the guide but unsure exactly when
@rylev do you have something you wanted to talk about?
unsure if there's someone else attending ...
One thing that came to my mind was if we can some how make progress on documenting certain parts of the compiler where no one who normally contributes to the guide has expertise in
I think if we wait around for someone to (just as an example) clean up and fill out how macro expansion works we might be waiting for a long time
(not to pick on anyone who is working on macro expansion in particular)
Is there any way we can encourage more active investigation into certain areas with the intent of documenting them?
yeah I wonder the same kind of things

rylev said:

Is there any way we can encourage more active investigation into certain areas with the intent of documenting them?

I think we could yeah
at some point we were very actively seeking for people that were able to talk with us about how certain things worked
we recorded and then tried to transcribe parts

Someone may be willing to contribute docs but not have an excuse to deep dive into a certain part of the compiler while others might have that excuse but not be interested in contributing to the guide.
also Niko was advocating for something like that yesterday on CTCFT

rylev said:

Someone may be willing to contribute docs but not have an excuse to deep dive into a certain part of the compiler while others might have that excuse but not be interested in contributing to the guide.

yeah, another way could be to just say ... let's investigate how X works and having all the wg investigating on that together and being able to ask questions and talk about things

I saw the issues we have for transcribing videos. My concern there is that that content requires a lot of background knowledge to be useful and it might be presented in a way that isn't really appropriate for a book like medium
another thing ... there are a lot of existing recordings that were not added to the guide

rylev said:

I saw the issues we have for transcribing videos. My concern there is that that content requires a lot of background knowledge to be useful and it might be presented in a way that isn't really appropriate for a book like medium

yeah
I don't really remember all the recordings we have, I guess what you say may be true for most of them, I wonder if it's true for all of them
maybe there are a couple that we can try to integrate into the guide
I would much prefer using those recordings as reference material, but not necessarily just straight transcribing them
I would be interested in doing some spelunking (there's a reason I brought up macro expansion), but it might be easier if others were involved.
yeah, when I say transcribe I don't mean literally
Do the sections link to the videos? That would at least people a place to start even if it's not a book format
I'd say use it as reference material and write things in an appropriate format for the guide

Joshua Nelson said:

Do the sections link to the videos? That would at least people a place to start even if it's not a book format

that's also a thing we could do, have links to the recordings from each corresponding section of the guide to all the recordings we did, talks, etc

By the way, if we do more recordings in the future, it might be useful to have some sort of template for them. There are some videos which just start in the middle of something with zero context. One video that I watched started with the sentence "so we were talking last week about issue 93283"
That's really not that approachable
hehehe :)
but yeah, definitely :+1: to what you say
do we want to take something in concrete out of this meeting?
to be honest since a while I'm a bit uncertain because I'm not having a lot of time to work on things on the guide, as I've said, that may change
Sorry, I couldn't attend this meeting as I've encountered some issues :(
